crnrstn_element.crnrstn_description:
The CRNRSTN Suite :: utilizes the ip_auth_manager class internally to apply any IP address configuration profiles communicated through the methods grantExclusiveAccess() and denyAccess() in the CRNRSTN Suite configuration file (_crnrstn.config.inc.php). Through these two methods, IP denials are applied globally to any resource standing on top of CRNRSTN with no exceptions.
However, there may be circumstances where applying a global IP block may be too extreme. Therefore, the ip_auth_manager class also comes with two sister methods to grantExclusiveAccess() and denyAccess()...created so that one could apply the same IP blocks...but with surgical precision. The methods exclusiveAccess() and denyIPAccess() can be passed a comma delimited list of IP addresses, and they will return BOOLEAN upon evaluating the results. Any necessary steps can then be taken within the application.

crnrstn_techspecscontent.crnrstn_techspec: It is recommended that you upgrade to the latest official release of PHP to take advantage of gains in security and processing efficiency together with the latest features and functionality.
Currently tested on an Ubuntu Server 16.04 running PHP 7.0.22/MySQLi 5.0.12 and CentOS 7 Linux (a 100% compatible rebuild of the Red Hat Enterprise Linux) running PHP 5.6.32/MySQLi 5.5.58.

I still need to do testing with IPv6 address handling to confirm that CRNRSTN Suite performs as expected in that area. If you have the ability to test the IPv6 address handling of the CRNRSTN Suite and give feedback, it would be much appreciated.
